qas.question: What was Tucker concerned the establishment clause could not preempt?

context: Others, such as Rep. Roger Sherman of <a0_0><b5_0>Connecticut<b5_0/><a0_0/>, believed the clause was unnecessary because the original <a1_0><b6_0>Constitution only gave Congress stated powers<b6_0/><a1_0/>, which did not include <a2_0><b7_0>establishing a national religion<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Anti-Federalists such as Rep. Thomas Tucker of <a3_0><b8_0>South Carolina<b8_0/><a3_0/> moved to strike the establishment clause completely because it could preempt the <a4_0><b9_0>religious clauses in the state constitutions<b9_0/><a4_0/>. However, the Anti-Federalists were unsuccessful in persuading the House of Representatives to drop the clause from the first amendment.
